key_points: Imagine the situation: you are heading East, and you start to increase your bank angle
Initially, the pendulous magnet inside your compass will still remain aligned with the magnetic North of the Earth
However, as you increase the bank angle even more, the dip, which is the angle between the horizontal plane and your magnet, will get increasingly higher
learning.explanation: Imagine the situation: you are heading East, and you start to increase your bank angle. Initially, the pendulous magnet inside your compass will still remain aligned with the magnetic North of the Earth. However, as you increase the bank angle even more, the dip, which is the angle between the horizontal plane and your magnet, will get increasingly higher. At some point, when the bank angle gets too big, the compass will just ‘fall’ and rotate 180° towards the lowest wing which is into the turn, and the compass will indicate West instead of East. Therefore, the total error of the compass would be 180° on an easterly heading in a steep right turn. Conclusion: beyond the critical bank angle (90 minus the dip angle), the compass will lag by 180 degrees when the aircraft is banked towards the equator. Nothern Hemisphere: HDG 090 -> right steep turn -> (dip + bank angle > 90) -> 180 error HDG 270 -> left steep turn -> (dip + bank angle > 90) -> 180 error

key_points: Magnetic dip is the natural phenomenon of the vertical component of the magnetic field over the earth's surface and its effect on the magnetic compass

The earth's magnetic field has two components or forces: a horizontal force parallel to the earth's surface that is used to align the compass with magnetic north and therefore to determine direction and a vertical force that causes the needle to dip down
At the magnetic equator, the horizontal force is dominant, and therefore, there is no dip and the compass is accurate
learning.explanation: Magnetic dip is the natural phenomenon of the vertical component of the magnetic field over the earth's surface and its effect on the magnetic compass. The earth's magnetic field has two components or forces: a horizontal force parallel to the earth's surface that is used to align the compass with magnetic north and therefore to determine direction and a vertical force that causes the needle to dip down. At the magnetic equator, the horizontal force is dominant, and therefore, there is no dip and the compass is accurate. However, as you move closer to either of the magnetic poles, the vertical component increases, and this induces the magnetic bar in the compass to dip down to align itself vertically with the magnetic field. Lines joining points of equal dip are called isoclinic lines, or magnetic latitudes. There is a magnetic latitude roughly near the equator where the dip is zero (referred to as aclinic line).

content.question: The Earth's north magnetic pole is…

options.A: located approximately in Northern Russia.
options.B: merged with the Earth`s true north.
options.C: located approximately in Northern Canada.
options.D: merged with the Earth`s north geographical pole.

key_points: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen
Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another
These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass
learning.explanation: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen. Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another. These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass. In fact, these magnetic lines are not straight lines spread equally around the Earth. They are straight and horizontal close to the equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. Therefore, they will become more and more inclined until being fully vertical at the pole. As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical and produce greater instrument errors (turning, acceleration…). The magnetic lines converge at the magnetic poles, which is different from the geographic pole (the axis around which the Earth is spinning). Another thing to consider is that the magnetic poles continuously change location. For instance, right now the magnetic North pole is situated approximately in Northern Canada, but it is moving at a rate of about 50km/year towards Siberia. On the other hand, the South magnetic pole is moving at around 15 km/year, the same rate at which the North magnetic pole used to move as well as a few years ago.

learning.explanation: Rigidity in space and precession are two main properties of a gyroscope. These properties are the basic principle of operation behind many attitude, heading, and inertial reference systems found in aircraft. Consider a gyroscope with its mass rotating about a given axis. If a force is applied on the rotating mass in its plane of rotation, the force will induce a torque about an axis situated 90° to its plane of rotation. Because the gyro’s mass is rotating, this force will be applied at a right angle to the gyroscope’s rotational axis. This is called gyroscopic precession. Rigidity determines how prone is the gyro to process torque on its spin axis as the airframe is displaced. This is the law of conservation of angular momentum. Concentrating the gyroscope’s mass at its periphery will give the instrument more stability which ultimately will improve its rigidity in space.

learning.explanation: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

Wander is subdivided into drift and topple. If the gyro axis wanders in the horizontal plane, it is called drift, either real or apparent. REAL WANDER In real wander, the axis of the gyro moves with respect to inertial space. This departure from the original orientation is caused by manufacturing imperfections, such as uneven rotor bearing friction, gimbal friction, imbalance in the mass of the rotor and unbalanced gimbals. Real wander can be reduced by higher quality engineering and manufacturing. Depending on the application, the cost of reducing real wander may not be justified by the level of accuracy required. Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references
learning.explanation: The artificial horizon gives the pilot an indication of the aircraft’s attitude in pitch and roll. It uses an Earth gyro which rotation axis is maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity. Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references. To maintain the rotor’s axis vertical in flight, the air driven artificial horizon will exhaust air through four slots, each of them being half covered by a pendulous vane. The four jets of air are equal in strength and will flow out the vanes in different directions when the airplane is in straight and level flight. This will keep the axis vertical and no precession will occur. However, if the rotor moves from its vertical position, one slot will completely obstruct the vane, while the opposite slot will leave the vane fully open. The resulting unbalanced airflow streaming out of the vanes will precess the gyro and return the gyro axis to the vertical. Additionally, the vanes will be affected by any acceleration, not just that due to gravity. content.question: During an acceleration in level flight, what would be the indicated effects on an artificial horizon?

options.A: Climb, left bank.
options.B: Climb, right bank.
options.C: Descent, right bank.

key_points: When accelerating in level flight, you would expect the artificial horizon (AH) to show wings level and a steady nose attitude
However, due to its construction, both the electrical and air driven AH will show a false attitude
This is because the force of acceleration affects their erection systems
learning.explanation: When accelerating in level flight, you would expect the artificial horizon (AH) to show wings level and a steady nose attitude. However, due to its construction, both the electrical and air driven AH will show a false attitude. This is because the force of acceleration affects their erection systems. The electrical AH will show a false climb. The air driven AH will show a false climb and a right turn. This question appears to be asking about an air driven version. The air-driven artificial horizon gives the pilot the aircraft's attitude relative to the horizon and is part of the essential set of instruments in any aircraft. It consists of an Earth gyro with its spin axis maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity, providing both pitch and roll indications. The basic air-driven artificial horizon is made pendulous and is maintained bottom-heavy to reduce erection time at start-up. The pendulous system consists of four pendulous vanes, partially open to leave air to flow outside. When the aircraft is not maneuvering, all four air jets are equal and exist the vanes equally. As soon as any acceleration is sensed, the vanes will be affected and will be erroneously displaced. For instance, when the aircraft is accelerating the result is a false pitch up and right-hand turn indication. In fact, since the vanes are hanging to the rotor, the lateral vanes will lag during acceleration and will tilt the vertical axis of the gyro, which is normally supposed always to be aligned with the Earth’s vertical. As a result, the horizon bar, moving in the same way as the outer gimbal, will tend to lower downwards (relative to the pilot’s position) and indicate a pitch up movement. Note: Both AH show a false nose up when accelerating, as seen in many other questions. The 2021 Learning Objectives focus more on the effect of acceleration, rather than the cause. That said, the electrical AH uses mercury switches to maintain the gyro axis vertical. In normal operation, the mercury sits at the bottom of the switch and the circuit is open. During an acceleration, the mercury is pushed out of position and closes the switch, ultimately driving the gyro to show a false climb. An air driven AH uses a pendulous unit and vanes to maintain the gyro axis vertical. During an acceleration, the force acts to disturb both the pendulous unit and the vanes, and this results in a false right climb indication.

learning.explanation: The rate of turn is the amount of heading change (in degrees) per unit of time (usually seconds) => change of heading rate of the aircraft. On the other hand, the yaw rate is the rate of rotation about the aircraft’s yaw axis. Yes, the heading will also change if you yaw the aircraft, so you can say that it is the same as the rate of turn. learning.explanation: A turn and slip indicator, also known as a turn-and-bank indicator, is a flight instrument that provides pilots with information about the aircraft's yawing motion. The instrument consists of a needle that indicates the rate of turn and a ball that indicates the slip or skid of the aircraft. If the needle is deflected and the ball is centered, this means that the aircraft is yawing, or turning around its vertical axis. Yawing can occur when the pilot uses the rudder to make the aircraft turn, or it can occur due to crosswinds or other factors that affect the aircraft's lateral stability. Drifting, Skidding and slipping are all related to the aircraft's sliding motion, and they are displayed in different ways on the turn and slip indicator. Skidding refers to the condition where the aircraft is turning and the ball is deflected to the outside of the turn. This is caused by too much rudder in the direction of the turn. Slipping refers to the condition where the aircraft is turning and the ball is deflected to the inside of the turn. This is caused by either too little rudder in the direction of the turn, or even the use of opposite rudder (adverse yaw). Drifting is the condition where the ball is displaced from the center in a straight and level flight, indicating that the aircraft is not aligned with the wind direction.

learning.explanation: The artificial horizon gives the pilot an indication of the aircraft’s attitude in pitch and roll. It uses an Earth gyro which rotation axis is maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity. Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references. To maintain the rotor’s axis vertical in flight, the air driven artificial horizon will exhaust air through four slots, each of them being half covered by a pendulous vane. The four jets of air are equal in strength and will flow out the vanes in different directions when the airplane is in straight and level flight. This will keep the axis vertical and no precession will occur. However, if the rotor moves from its vertical position, one slot will completely obstruct the vane, while the opposite slot will leave the vane fully open. The resulting unbalanced airflow streaming out of the vanes will precess the gyro and return the gyro axis to the vertical. Additionally, the vanes will be affected by any acceleration, not just that due to gravity. For instance, when an aircraft accelerates in straight and level flight, or during the take-off run, a false nose-up indication will occur. The pitch error is due to the effect of acceleration on the lateral pendulous vanes.

learning.explanation: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

key_points: The simplest form of gyroscope (or gyro) consists of a rapidly spinning disc (called a rotor)

Any rapidly spinning symmetrical rotor exhibits gyroscopic properties: - Precession: When an external force is applied to the spinning rotor via the gimbal assembly, the gyro does not move in the direction of the force, but in a direction perpendicular (90° later) to that of the applied force
- Rigidity: Rigidity is the gyro’s property of maintaining its axis in a fixed direction in space unless subjected to an external force
learning.explanation: The simplest form of gyroscope (or gyro) consists of a rapidly spinning disc (called a rotor). Any rapidly spinning symmetrical rotor exhibits gyroscopic properties: - Precession: When an external force is applied to the spinning rotor via the gimbal assembly, the gyro does not move in the direction of the force, but in a direction perpendicular (90° later) to that of the applied force. - Rigidity: Rigidity is the gyro’s property of maintaining its axis in a fixed direction in space unless subjected to an external force. It is caused by the inertia of the spinning mass. The shaft about which the rotor spins is called the axis. Gyros are defined in their orientation as either horizontal or vertical by reference to the spin axis, not the rotor. Despite the property of rigidity, the orientation of a gyro axis may alter over time. Any departure of a gyro axis from its original orientation is called wander. Wander may be either real or apparent (the difference is explained below) or a combination of both. Wander is subdivided into drift and topple. If the gyro axis wanders in the horizontal plane, it is called drift, either real or apparent. (figure 1) If the gyro axis wanders in the vertical plane, it is called topple, either real or apparent. learning.explanation: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. learning.explanation: A turn and slip indicator, also known as a turn-and-bank indicator, is a flight instrument that provides pilots with information about the aircraft's yawing motion. The instrument consists of a needle that indicates the rate of turn and a ball that indicates the slip or skid of the aircraft. If the needle is deflected and the ball is centered, this means that the aircraft is yawing, or turning around its vertical axis. Yawing can occur when the pilot uses the rudder to make the aircraft turn, or it can occur due to crosswinds or other factors that affect the aircraft's lateral stability. Drifting, Skidding and slipping are all related to the aircraft's sliding motion, and they are displayed in different ways on the turn and slip indicator. Skidding refers to the condition where the aircraft is turning and the ball is deflected to the outside of the turn. This is caused by too much rudder in the direction of the turn. Slipping refers to the condition where the aircraft is turning and the ball is deflected to the inside of the turn. This is caused by either too little rudder in the direction of the turn, or even the use of opposite rudder (adverse yaw). Drifting is the condition where the ball is displaced from the center in a straight and level flight, indicating that the aircraft is not aligned with the wind direction.

learning.explanation: Real Wander vs Apparent Wander Real Wander applies to situations where the gyro axis actually alters its orientation in space. This is due to precession resulting in undesired forces affecting the spin axis orientation. Apparent Wander applies to situations where the gyroscope is not really moving. As the Earth spins around its axis, the orientation of the space-rigid gyroscope changes with respect to the surface of the Earth, giving an observer the impression that the gyroscope is actually changing its orientation. content.question: When the aircraft accelerates, the attitude indicator gives a false pitch up indication. Why does this happen?

options.A: The spin axis is displaced from the vertical.
options.B: The apparent vertical is deflected towards the outer sides.
options.C: The apparent vertical is tilting forward.
options.D: The height of the pilot’s eyes relative to the instrument causes an apparent shift when the aircraft accelerates.

key_points: Errors in the indications presented on the attitude indicator will result from any factor that prevents the vacuum system from operating within the design suction limits, or from any force that disturbs the free rotation of the gyro at design speed
Gravity erection is essential for the operation of an artificial horizon
However, accelerations occur during flight which cannot be distinguished from gravitational accelerations, induce indication errors
learning.explanation: Errors in the indications presented on the attitude indicator will result from any factor that prevents the vacuum system from operating within the design suction limits, or from any force that disturbs the free rotation of the gyro at design speed. Gravity erection is essential for the operation of an artificial horizon. However, accelerations occur during flight which cannot be distinguished from gravitational accelerations, induce indication errors. The erection system therefore tries to align the gyro axis with the apparent vertical. During acceleration, the erection system is unable to distinguish between acceleration caused by gravity (in the direction of the local vertical) and the inertia of its sensor. As a result, the apparent vertical is inclined to the rear (spin axis is displaced from the vertical) and causes a higher pitch indication. In simple words, the horizon bar moves down, indicating a climb. Deceleration causes the apparent vertical to tilt forwards, reducing the perceived pitch attitude.

key_points: Rigidity in space and precession are two main properties of a gyroscope
These properties are the basic principle of operation behind many attitude, heading, and inertial reference systems found in aircraft
Consider a gyroscope with its mass rotating about a given axis
learning.explanation: Rigidity in space and precession are two main properties of a gyroscope. These properties are the basic principle of operation behind many attitude, heading, and inertial reference systems found in aircraft. Consider a gyroscope with its mass rotating about a given axis. If a force is applied on the rotating mass in its plane of rotation, the force will induce a torque about an axis situated 90° to its plane of rotation. Because the gyro’s mass is rotating, this force will be applied at a right angle to the gyroscope’s rotational axis. This is called gyroscopic precession. Rigidity determines how prone is the gyro to process torque on its spin axis as the airframe is displaced. This is the law of conservation of angular momentum. Concentrating the gyroscope’s mass at its periphery will give the instrument more stability which ultimately will improve its rigidity in space.

content.question: The artificial horizon uses a gyroscope with…

options.A: two degrees of freedom, and an automatic erection system attempts to align its rotor spin axis to the local vertical.
options.B: one degree of freedom, and an automatic erection system attempts to align its rotor spin axis with the horizontal plane.
options.C: one degree of freedom, and an automatic erection system attempts to align its rotor spin axis to the local vertical.
options.D: two degrees of freedom, and an automatic erection system attempts to align its rotor spin axis with the horizontal plane.

key_points: The artificial horizon gives the pilot an indication of the aircraft’s attitude in pitch and roll
It uses an Earth gyro which rotation axis is maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity
Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references
learning.explanation: The artificial horizon gives the pilot an indication of the aircraft’s attitude in pitch and roll. It uses an Earth gyro which rotation axis is maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity. Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references. To maintain the rotor’s axis vertical in flight, the air driven artificial horizon will exhaust air through four slots, each of them being half covered by a pendulous vane. The four jets of air are equal in strength and will flow out the vanes in different directions when the airplane is in straight and level flight. This will keep the axis vertical and no precession will occur. However, if the rotor moves from its vertical position, one slot will completely obstruct the vane, while the opposite slot will leave the vane fully open. The resulting unbalanced airflow streaming out of the vanes will precess the gyro and return the gyro axis to the vertical. Additionally, the vanes will be affected by any acceleration, not just that due to gravity. For instance, when an aircraft accelerates in straight and level flight, or during the take-off run, a false nose-up indication will occur. The pitch error is due to the effect of acceleration on the lateral pendulous vanes. Additionally, some more sophisticated artificial horizons are electrically driven and maintain the rotor’s axis vertical by using two mercury level switches and two torque motors.

learning.explanation: The Slip Indicator It is desirable that turns should be properly balanced, with no side slip or skid. This implies that the angle of bank should be correct for the TAS and rate of turn. The slip indicator gives a direct indication of the state of balance of the turn. This comprises a solid ball in a curved tube containing liquid with damps out the unwanted oscillations. The heavy ball behaves like a pendulum, with the centre of curvature of the tube acting as the effective point of suspension. Operating Principles Consider first the aircraft in level flight with lift L balancing weight W (figure 1). The weight W of the ball in the tube acts downwards and is exactly balanced by the equal and opposite reaction of the base of the tube on the ball, acting upwards towards the centre of curvature of the tube. If the wings are level, the ball will lie just between the two vertical lines etched on the tube. Now let us consider a balanced turn to the left (figure 2). The aircraft with lift L equal and opposite to the resultant of aircraft weight W and centrifugal force C, the latter being proportional to TAS and rate of turn. The ball is also subject to a centrifugal force depending on TAS and rate of turn, so it rolls outwards, taking up a new equilibrium position such that the reaction of the base of the tube on the ball is again exactly balanced, this time by the resultant of ball weight W and centrifugal force C.

content.question: Which of the following most accurately defines the apparent wander of a gyroscope?

key_points: Any departure of a gyro axis from its original orientation is called wander
Wander may be either real or apparent (the difference is explained below) or a combination of both
Wander is subdivided into drift and topple
learning.explanation: Any departure of a gyro axis from its original orientation is called wander. Wander may be either real or apparent (the difference is explained below) or a combination of both. Wander is subdivided into drift and topple. If the gyro axis wanders in the horizontal plane, it is called drift, either real or apparent. APPARENT WANDER In this type of wander, the gyro spin axis does not physically wander away from its pre-set direction, but to an observer it appears to have changed its direction. This is because the gyro maintains its direction with respect to a fixed point in space, whereas the observer rotates with the Earth, thus with the passage of time the gyro appears to have changed direction, with reference to an Earth datum. Apparent wander, is also made up of horizontal components called drift, and vertical components called topple. The rate of drift and topple depends upon the latitude and can vary from zero to a maximum of 15.04° per hour (the rate at which the Earth rotates).

options.B: earth rate wander.
options.C: real wander.

key_points: Any departure of a gyro axis from its original orientation is called wander
Wander may be either real or apparent (the difference is explained below) or a combination of both

learning.explanation: Any departure of a gyro axis from its original orientation is called wander. Wander may be either real or apparent (the difference is explained below) or a combination of both. Wander is subdivided into drift and topple. If the gyro axis wanders in the horizontal plane, it is called drift, either real or apparent. REAL WANDER In real wander, the axis of the gyro moves with respect to inertial space. This departure from the original orientation is caused by manufacturing imperfections, such as uneven rotor bearing friction, gimbal friction, imbalance in the mass of the rotor and unbalanced gimbals. Real wander can be reduced by higher quality engineering and manufacturing. Depending on the application, the cost of reducing real wander may not be justified by the level of accuracy required. As with instrument error, gyros need to be as accurate as the need of the application in use, but over-engineering costs extra money. Real wander can also be known as ‘random’ wander.

key_points: The artificial horizon gives the pilot an indication of the aircraft’s attitude in pitch and roll
It uses an Earth gyro which rotation axis is maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity
Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references
learning.explanation: The artificial horizon gives the pilot an indication of the aircraft’s attitude in pitch and roll. It uses an Earth gyro which rotation axis is maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity. Therefore, the rotating mass of the gyro spins in the horizontal plane giving stable lateral and longitudinal references. To maintain the rotor’s axis vertical in flight, the air driven artificial horizon will exhaust air through four slots, each of them being half covered by a pendulous vane. The four jets of air are equal in strength and will flow out the vanes in different directions when the airplane is in straight and level flight. This will keep the axis vertical and no precession will occur. However, if the rotor moves from its vertical position, one slot will completely obstruct the vane, while the opposite slot will leave the vane fully open. The resulting unbalanced airflow streaming out of the vanes will precess the gyro and return the gyro axis to the vertical. Additionally, the vanes will be affected by any acceleration, not just that due to gravity. For instance, when an aircraft accelerates in straight and level flight, or during the take-off run, a false nose-up indication will occur. The pitch error is due to the effect of acceleration on the lateral pendulous vanes.

options.B: directional gyro unit.

key_points: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope
The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors
The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro
learning.explanation: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

content.question: Considering an air-driven Artificial Horizon, when an aircraft accelerates during a take-off run the result is…

options.A: Nothing happens, the AI can account for this
options.B: A False down pitch indication
options.C: A False bank to one side

key_points: The air-driven artificial horizon gives the pilot the aircraft's attitude relative to the horizon and is part of the essential set of instruments in any aircraft
It consists of an Earth gyro with its spin axis maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity, providing both pitch and roll indications
The basic air-driven artificial horizon is made pendulous and is maintained bottom-heavy to reduce erection time at start-up
learning.explanation: The air-driven artificial horizon gives the pilot the aircraft's attitude relative to the horizon and is part of the essential set of instruments in any aircraft. It consists of an Earth gyro with its spin axis maintained vertical by Earth’s gravity, providing both pitch and roll indications. The basic air-driven artificial horizon is made pendulous and is maintained bottom-heavy to reduce erection time at start-up. The pendulous system consists of four pendulous vanes, partially open to leave air to flow outside. When the aircraft is not maneuvering, all four air jets are equal and exist the vanes equally. As soon as any acceleration is sensed, the vanes will be affected and will be erroneously displaced. For instance, when the aircraft is accelerating, for example, during a take-off run, the result is a false pitch up and right-hand turn indication. In fact, since the vanes are hanging to the rotor, the lateral vanes will lag during acceleration and will tilt the vertical axis of the gyro, which is normally supposed always to be aligned with the Earth’s vertical. As a result, the horizon bar, moving in the same way as the outer gimbal, will tend to lower downwards (relative to the pilot’s position) and indicate a pitch up movement.

learning.explanation: ATTITUDE & HEADING REFERENCE SYSTEM (AHRS) An attitude and heading reference system (AHRS) uses an inertial measurement unit (IMU) consisting of microelectromechanical system (MEMS) inertial sensors to measure the angular rate, acceleration, and Earth's magnetic field. These measurements can be used to determine the aircraft's attitude. SYSTEM COMPONENTS An AHRS typically includes a 3-axis gyroscope, a 3-axis accelerometer, and a 3-axis magnetometer. GYROSCOPE A gyroscope provides an AHRS with a measurement of the aircraft's angular rate. Each angular rate is integrated to determine the aircraft's attitude. ACCELEROMETER An accelerometer supplies an AHRS with a measure of the aircraft's acceleration and is assumed to be measuring gravity alone. This assumption allows the accelerometer to calculate the pitch and roll angles from the direction of the gravity vector. MAGNETOMETER Since the accelerometer can only measure pitch & roll, a magnetometer provides an AHRS with a measurement of yaw by comparing the measurement of the magnetic field surrounding the aircraft to Earth's magnetic field, just like a traditional magnetic compass.

learning.explanation: To overcome the problems of the Directional Gyro Indicator, a Gyro-magnetic compass (remote-reading compass) may be used. The Directional gyroscope drifts over time, therefore, at regular intervals, the pilot must manually synchronise it with the direct reading compass. The Remote-reading compass' main direction indication comes from a directional gyroscope, which is kept from drifting by tying it to the output of a flux valve unit for magnetic reference. The operation of the gyro-magnetic compass can be controlled in the cockpit through the Compass Control Panel which has two positions: SLAVE or FREE. content.question: Why does an air-driven gyroscope attitude indicator give erroneous indications during acceleration?

options.A: The erecting system of the instrument displaces the spin axis from vertical.
options.B: The aircraft symbol is set for straight, level and accelerated flight only.
options.C: The spin axis is aligned to the vertical only for the position of alignment.

key_points: AIR DRIVEN ARTIFICIAL HORIZON (figure 1) In a gyroscopic attitude indicator system, the rotor assembly is made very slightly bottom-heavy in order to keep down the time taken for initial erection when the gyro is first started up, but a complex control system is required to maintain the rotor axis vertical in flight

The control system of the air driven artificial horizon consists of four slots and four pendulous vanes at the base of the rotor housing, so that when the rotor axis is vertical each slot is half covered by its vane
Because the four jets are of equal strength but in opposite directions no force is exerted on the gyro and therefore no precession occurs - the gyro rotor remaining vertical
learning.explanation: AIR DRIVEN ARTIFICIAL HORIZON (figure 1) In a gyroscopic attitude indicator system, the rotor assembly is made very slightly bottom-heavy in order to keep down the time taken for initial erection when the gyro is first started up, but a complex control system is required to maintain the rotor axis vertical in flight. The control system of the air driven artificial horizon consists of four slots and four pendulous vanes at the base of the rotor housing, so that when the rotor axis is vertical each slot is half covered by its vane. Because the four jets are of equal strength but in opposite directions no force is exerted on the gyro and therefore no precession occurs - the gyro rotor remaining vertical. The opposing vanes are fixed to a common spindle so that the four vanes operate as two pairs. The positioning of the vanes is such that if the rotor axis wanders from the vertical, one vane will hang clear of its slot, allowing unrestricted airflow, while the opposite slot is completely obstructed by its vane. The resulting unbalanced airflow precesses the gyro and corrects the tilt, returning the gyro axis to the vertical. ACCELERATION ERROR (figure 2) The control system of the air driven artificial horizon depends on the pendulous vanes being affected by the earth’s gravity. However, the vanes will be affected by any acceleration, not just that due to gravity. When an aircraft accelerates in a level attitude (such as during the take-off run) a false nose- up, right wing down, or climbing right hand turn indication will result. During acceleration, the lateral vanes lag, swinging back towards the pilot, opening the starboard slot and closing the port slot. This results in a reaction which acts to port. By the rule of precession the effect on the gyro is as if the direction of application of the Reaction had been moved 90° in the direction of rotor spin (anticlockwise). The gyro will now be precessed out of vertical with the base moving backwards towards the pilot. This movement is transmitted via the guide pin and horizon bar arm to bring the horizon bar below the gull-wing giving a nose-up indication. Due to inertia, the weighted base of the rotor housing tries to lag during acceleration. This force will be precessed, resulting in the base of the rotor housing moving to starboard and the gyro axis precessing out of the vertical. This rotates the whole rotor / gimbal assembly about the longitudinal axis to give a right wing down indication.

learning.explanation: ATTITUDE & HEADING REFERENCE SYSTEM (AHRS) An attitude and heading reference system (AHRS) uses an inertial measurement unit (IMU) consisting of microelectromechanical system (MEMS) inertial sensors to measure the angular rate, acceleration, and Earth's magnetic field. These measurements can be used to determine the aircraft's attitude. SYSTEM COMPONENTS An AHRS typically includes a 3-axis gyroscope, a 3-axis accelerometer, and a 3-axis magnetometer. Gyroscope - A gyroscope provides an AHRS with a measurement of the aircraft's angular rate. Each angular rate is integrated to determine the aircraft's attitude. Accelerometer - An accelerometer supplies an AHRS with a measure of the aircraft's acceleration and is assumed to be measuring gravity alone. This assumption allows the accelerometer to calculate the pitch and roll angles from the direction of the gravity vector. Magnetometer - Since the accelerometer can only measure pitch & roll, a magnetometer provides an AHRS with a measurement of yaw by comparing the measurement of the magnetic field surrounding the aircraft to Earth's magnetic field, just like a traditional magnetic compass.

key_points: Learning Objective 022
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 022.05.01.01.03: State that earlier gyro mechanically stabilised platforms are (technically incorrectly but conventionally) referred to as inertial navigation systems (INSs) and more modern fixed (strap down) platforms are conventionally referred to as inertial reference systems (IRSs). INSs can be considered to be stand-alone, whereas IRSs are integrated with the FMS. The wording of these options seems to be almost intentionally difficult to understand. To start, we need to realise that EASA are referring to a stabilised platform INS when they call something an inertial navigation system, as per the above learning objective. These are systems that, once aligned, have a platform that remains level and pointing towards the North, which is controlled by rate-integrating gyros and servo motors to keep the platform in that orientation. By inputting the initial location when the INS is aligned and kept still, the system can then track every acceleration in the North/South and East/West axis to keep a track of speed and therefore distance travelled along those axes. Therefore, there is still a reference for this system, the North direction and which way is up. The platform then endeavours to maintain these references during flight. More modern systems using the same idea are called strapdown IRSs. They are much smaller and cheaper, and are fixed to the aircraft structure, measuring the accelerations and rotations of the aircraft and applying them in a computer model of the Earth to provide an improved version of an INS.

key_points: The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground
A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform

learning.explanation: The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground. A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform. Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary). Moreover, by detecting the drift due to the earth’s rotation, the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) will be able to internally calculate the True North. Latitude can also be internally calculated, but because this calculation is not sufficiently precise, a manual position input is required from the flight crew for this alignment sequence. Therefore, the system will compare the inserted latitude with the calculated one and compute precisely the aircraft’s position. On the other hand, the IRS cannot calculate/measure longitude, therefore the only reference is the one provided by the pilot during the alignment process.

These are much lighter, and less complex to have on board, as they use a set of 3-ring laser gyroscopes and 3 accelerometers to measure all the rotations and accelerations, and then calculate into their various components (North-South, East-West, and Vertical) using modern computer methods. key_points: The Inertial Navigation System (INS) receives data from three rate gyros, and two internal accelerometers measuring accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions
Accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions are measured by the accelerometers and are integrated
Acceleration integrated over time: Once = change in velocity
learning.explanation: The Inertial Navigation System (INS) receives data from three rate gyros, and two internal accelerometers measuring accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions. Accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions are measured by the accelerometers and are integrated. Acceleration integrated over time: Once = change in velocity. Twice = change in position. It is also true if we state that integrating velocity once over time gives the change in position. Internally, this is calculated by integrators that are time multiplication devices. Initially, acceleration is supplied to the integrator as a value in ft/sec². Multiplying a value in ft/sec² by another value in sec will give you a result in ft/sec => velocity. Velocity is basically how fast has the aircraft moved in feet per second. Then, this value is sent to another integrator to derive the change in position and determine the current position of the aircraft. In other words, a value in ft/sec is multiplied again by a value in seconds, which will result in a value in feet or NM => distance. The second integration will provide the IRS with the distance traveled, but if the initial position AND speed are known as well, the IRS will output the instantaneous position. Additional Input(s) Output ACCELERATION Once Initial SPEED Instantaneous SPEED ACCELERATION Once ----- Change in SPEED (velocity) ACCELERATION TWICE Initial POSITION + Initial SPEED Instantaneous POSITION ACCELERATION TWICE ----- POSITION SPEED ONCE ----- DISTANCE traveled

key_points: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro
Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes
Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro
learning.explanation: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro. Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes. Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro. The RLG is produced from a block of a very stable glass ceramic compound, which has an extremely low coefficient of expansion. The triangular cavity contains a mixture of helium and neon gases at low pressure through which a current is passed. Lasing is achieved by running high voltages through helium neon gas between the anodes and the cathode transforming many of the atoms of the gas into light in the pinkish orange part of the visible spectrum (this action is helped by the tuned cavity effect of the tunnel in the glass block). The laser beam is forced to travel in both directions around the cavity. Thus, for a stationary block, the travelled paths are identical, and the frequencies of the two beams are the same at any sampling point. If the block is rotated, the effective path lengths differ; one increases, and the other decreases. Sampling at any point gives different frequencies, and if the frequency change is processed, it gives both an angular change, and a rate of angular change. By processing the difference in frequency between the two-pulsed light paths, the RLG is used as both a displacement, and as a rate gyro.

learning.explanation: Inertial Navigation means the determination of a vehicle’s location without the aid of external references. The Inertial Reference System (IRS) is a key component of an aircraft's inertial navigation system which is usually combined with a GPS receiver and sensor fusion software to show the flight crew where the plane is at any given moment even when GPS signals are not available. An IRS does not rely on conventional gyroscopes with masses spinning at high speeds (like INS). Instead, the system uses ring laser gyros (RLGs) that are attached to the aircraft structure in a specific orientation, and are therefore referred to as strapped-down. The coordinate system for computations is composed of the 3 aircraft axes. The IRS updates the aircraft's position by sensing its accelerations and integrating those movements with respect to time which establishes the direction of movement and distance from the start position. It is, therefore, independent of any externally generated (man-made) signals/visual references.

learning.explanation: INS errors can be divided into two categories: bounded and unbounded errors. A bounded error will increase to its maximum and return to zero within 84.4 minutes Schuler cycle, while unbounded errors are cumulative track errors or distance errors (they are getting bigger and bigger with time). The question is asking how these unbounded errors are affecting the system over time since they are the only cumulative errors. In fact, they increase proportionally with time, which means that the error increases as ‘t’ increases. Bounded errors are usually the following: Initial misalignment may not be conducted 100% correctly (aircraft shaking due to ground equipment positioning, crew activity, etc.) There can always be some errors due to the initial misalignment. Accelerators are mechanical systems consisting of a pendulous mechanism, pickoffs and servos that suffer all from the standard instrument error (manufacturing imperfections). Integrators make errors in the first stage of integration due to the incorrect inputs provided (listed in the points above). Unbounded errors are usually the following: Initial azimuth misalignment of the platform. Drift of the gyroscopes of the platform, which are the main source of error.

options.B: (1) acceleration; (2) height; (3) present position

key_points: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration
This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night
The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information
learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. This system is composed of a stable platform consisting of high quality gyros and accelerometers and a computer. The purpose of the computer is to integrate the accelerometer outputs with time to give velocity and then integrate velocity with time to give distance travelled. From this is available pitch and roll attitude, true heading, true track, drift, present position in latitude and longitude, ground speed and wind. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. These acceleration measuring devices sense any change in the aircraft’s velocity either as an acceleration or deceleration very accurately. The acceleration signal from the amplifier is sent to an integrator which is a time multiplication device. It starts out with acceleration which is in feet per second squared. In the integrator, it is multiplied by time and the result is a velocity in feet per second. With an input of feet per second, it is then sent through a second integrator, which is multiplied by time, the result is a distance in feet or nautical miles. The computer associated with the inertial system knows the latitude and longitude of the take-off point and calculates that the aircraft has travelled so far in the north and east direction. The computer can then compute the new position of the aircraft and give a digital read-out.

learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Gyro-stabilised platforms are generally costly, heavy, and require a lengthy alignment procedure. With the introduction of relatively low cost, high-performance digital computers, these systems have been steadily replaced by mathematical computer software models, which modify the output signals from accelerometers that are strapped directly to the airframe. Referred to as an inertial reference system (IRS), it works on the same fundamental principles as the INS. The strap-down system dispenses with the gimbal mounted stable element and instead uses solid-state ring laser gyros (RLG). These gyros are not required to stabilise the accelerometers, as in the case of an INS, but provide aeroplane orientation, by determining the rate of rotation around each of the aeroplane axes. Input data is also required, such as the: TAS - to calculate the wind speed/direction. Initial position – because actual aircraft position during the flight is calculated based on the distance and direction flown from the initial reference position entered in the system. Barometric altitude – the platform can output the inertial height by itself, but its accuracy is insufficient for precise height control, hence the barometric altitude input. GNSS (GPS) Position - in order to bound the INS position error. Other inptus are: Mach Number, Radio height, Number of satellites and Angle of attack. Note: The correct option was selected according to EASA LO 022.05.01.01.02 which states 'State that inertial systems require no external input, except TAS, to determine aircraft attitude and navigational data.' learning.explanation: Inertial Navigation means the determination of a vehicle’s location without the aid of external references. An Inertial Reference System (IRS) is a more modern and advanced version of the traditional inertial navigation system (INS) used in aviation. The main difference between the two systems is that an IRS uses solid-state sensors, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) accelerometers and gyroscopes, instead of traditional mechanical gyroscopes and accelerometers. Some of the main advantages of the more modern IRS are: - The solid-state sensors are more reliable and require less maintenance compared to mechanical gyroscopes. They also provide higher accuracy and faster response times, resulting in more precise and smoother navigation. -It consists of three RLGs that measure angular rates and three internal accelerometers measuring acceleration on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). The laser gyros allow a microprocessor to maintain a stable platform mathematically, rather than mechanically. - The IRS can be integrated with other navigation systems, such as GPS or ground-based radio beacons, to provide even more accurate and reliable navigation information. - IRS systems also have the ability to compensate for various types of errors that may affect the accuracy of the navigation data. For example, errors caused by temperature changes, sensor drift, or other external factors.

content.question: How does an IRS work?

options.A: It consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate acceleration.
options.B: The IRS is located close to the aircraft C/G and it uses laser gyros to calculate angular rotations.
options.C: The IRS is located a bit away from the aircraft C/G and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations.
options.D: The IRS is most reliable using lower frequency laser beams.

key_points: An IRS does not rely on conventional gyroscopes with masses spinning at high speeds (like INS)
Instead, the system uses ring laser gyros (RLGs) that are attached to the aircraft structure in a specific orientation, and are therefore referred to as strapped-down
The coordinate system for computations is composed of the 3 aircraft axes
learning.explanation: An IRS does not rely on conventional gyroscopes with masses spinning at high speeds (like INS). Instead, the system uses ring laser gyros (RLGs) that are attached to the aircraft structure in a specific orientation, and are therefore referred to as strapped-down. The coordinate system for computations is composed of the 3 aircraft axes. The IRS uses 3 accelerometers and 3 RLGs that are installed at right angles to one another to measure linear accelerations and rotations around the aircraft axes. A high-performance computer creates a virtual stabilised platform that is kept aligned by using information from the gyros. Note that there is no physical platform that is kept aligned/level. In flight, the aircraft moves around the centre of gravity (CG). Placing the IRS unit close to the CG improves the reliability of the readings and reduces the amount of IRS drift experienced. RLGs produce two, constant, high-frequency beams of light that travel over a system of mirrors/through fibreoptics, in opposite directions. When the RLG is at rest, the signal from both beams is identical. When a RLG is rotated about its sensitive axis, both beams are affected by the Doppler effect. One is red shifted, and the other blue shifted. This causes a phase difference which can be interpreted by the computer to map motion. "The IRS is located a bit away from the aircraft CG and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations." INCORRECT. The laser gyros do not detect accelerations - accelerometers do that job. Furthermore, as stated above, it is located close to the CG of the aircraft. "It consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate acceleration." INCORRECT. The older stable-platform INS uses gyros and accelerometers on a level platform. "The IRS is most reliable using lower frequency laser beams." INCORRECT. Laser gyros use a high frequency excitation of the laser gas, not low frequency.

This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. LEVELLING AND ALIGNMENT For a conventional gyro system, the process of levelling and alignment takes approximately 15 to 20 minutes. It is important that the aeroplane does not move during this process, because the resultant accelerations upset the system, preventing the platform from aligning. This process also requires corrections to be applied, which are dependent on the system being ‘told’ the accurate value of the present latitude and longitude. The alignment process is unsuccessful if the wrong latitude is initially entered into the system; if the error is small, it leads to poor alignment and degraded accuracy. If the latitude error is large, the platform is unable to align. If the longitude is however wrongly inserted during the initialisation process, it does not adversely affect the alignment process, but will affect the accuracy of any subsequent position. This is because the INS is a direct reading system, and if you start with a wrong position all subsequent positions are wrong.

key_points: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro

learning.explanation: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro. Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes. Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro. The RLG is produced from a block of a very stable glass ceramic compound, which has an extremely low coefficient of expansion. The triangular cavity contains a mixture of helium and neon gases at low pressure through which a current is passed. Lasing is achieved by running high voltages through helium neon gas between the anodes and the cathode transforming many of the atoms of the gas into light in the pinkish orange part of the visible spectrum (this action is helped by the tuned cavity effect of the tunnel in the glass block). The laser beam is forced to travel in both directions around the cavity. Thus, for a stationary block, the travelled paths are identical, and the frequencies of the two beams are the same at any sampling point. If the block is rotated, the effective path lengths differ; one increases, and the other decreases. Sampling at any point gives different frequencies, and if the frequency change is processed, it gives both an angular change, and a rate of angular change. By processing the difference in frequency between the two-pulsed light paths, the RLG is used as both a displacement, and as a rate gyro.

The main difference between the two systems is that an IRS uses solid-state sensors, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) accelerometers and gyroscopes, instead of traditional mechanical gyroscopes and accelerometers. Some of the main advantages of the more modern IRS are: - The solid-state sensors are more reliable and require less maintenance compared to mechanical gyroscopes. They also provide higher accuracy and faster response times, resulting in more precise and smoother navigation - The IRS can be integrated with other navigation systems, such as GPS or ground-based radio beacons, to provide even more accurate and reliable navigation information. - IRS systems also have the ability to compensate for various types of errors that may affect the accuracy of the navigation data. For example, errors caused by temperature changes, sensor drift, or other external factors. While traditional INS systems using mechanical gyroscopes and stand-alone computers are still in use in many aircraft today, IRS systems offer several advantages over their predecessors, including higher accuracy, faster response times, and better reliability.

learning.explanation: The ring laser gyro (RLG) is a modern, more sophisticated alternative to the conventional gyroscope. It is used for the aircraft inertial navigation systems and attitude/heading reference systems. It is a very accurate system to measure rotation about a given axis and is widespread in modern commercial aircraft IRS systems. Conventional gyro’s rotation mass is replaced by two contra-rotating beams of light. The case of the RLG is made of a vitreous ceramic material of low-temperature coefficient. Two gas-tight openings are carefully designed into the single-piece case of the RLG, which are then filled with inert gas, such as a mixture of Helium and Neon. A direct current electrical discharge ionizes the gas and creates two beams of light flowing in opposite directions in the two cavities of the RLG case. In order to produce a continuous laser circuit in the enclosed area of the RLG’s case, a set of mirrors is installed to reflect and trap the laser beams. The frequency of oscillation of each beam depends on the optical path length and corresponds to the cavity resonance condition. When the RLG is stationary, both optical path lengths of each beam are identical. However, when the RLG is rotated about the axis perpendicular to the laser beams plane, one beam will travel a larger distance, and the other will cover a shorter distance. learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Gyro-stabilised platforms are generally costly, heavy, and require a lengthy alignment procedure. With the introduction of relatively low cost, high-performance digital computers, these systems have been steadily replaced by mathematical computer software models, which modify the output signals from accelerometers that are strapped directly to the airframe. Referred to as an inertial reference system (IRS), it works on the same fundamental principles as the INS. The strap-down system dispenses with the gimbal mounted stable element and instead uses solid-state ring laser gyros (RLG). These gyros are not required to stabilise the accelerometers, as in the case of an INS, but provide aeroplane orientation, by determining the rate of rotation around each of the aeroplane axes.

learning.explanation: The Inertial Navigation System is a self-contained system that can provide continuous information on the aircraft's position, track, heading, groundspeed and, if necessary, height without any external assistance. Most aircraft of any size will be fitted with at least two inertial systems. The duplication is for redundancy and so that the information can be compared for possible error. The starting point for an inertial navigation system is acceleration. If acceleration is known, then the aircraft's speed can be calculated. If the speed is known, the distance travelled can be calculated. To solve a complete navigation problem in space, we need to know the acceleration in three axes at right angles to each other. The inertial system relates its acceleration to the three axes and recognizes the direction, using three methods: Stable Platform or Stabilised Inertial Platform Wander Angle Strapdown The Stable Platform, which keeps the platform, on which the accelerometers are mounted, always level and aligned to North, and also measures acceleration relative to the platform. Alignment and levelling is done only once for each flight with the aircraft stationary on the ground. Once aligned, the inertial system is not and cannot be re-aligned for the remainder of the flight. key_points: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration
This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night
The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information
learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. The quality of information is dependent on the accuracy of the initial (input) data, and the precision with which the system aligns to True North. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. To keep the reference valid, the accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Rate integrating gyros are for use as sensors to detect any departure of the platform from its level and desired alignment. BOUNDED ERRORS These errors build up to a maximum positive and negative values, and return to zero within each 84.4 minutes Schuler cycle and thus averages out over the period. The main causes of these errors are: - platform tilt, due to initial misalignment - inaccurate measurement of acceleration by accelerometers - integrator errors in the first integration stage UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE TRACK ERRORS These errors arise from the misalignment of the accelerometers in the horizontal plane, and the main causes of these errors are: - Initial azimuth misalignment of the platform. - Wander of the azimuth gyro. UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE DISTANCE ERROR These errors give rise to cumulative errors in the recording of the total distance travelled. The main causes of this error are: - Wander in the levelling gyros. - Integrator errors in the second stage of integration. INHERENT ERRORS The irregular shape and composition of the Earth, together with the movement of the Earth through space, and other factors provide further possible sources of error. Such errors vary from system to system, depending upon the balance achieved between accuracy on one hand and the simplicity of design, reliability, ease of construction and cost of production on the other.

learning.explanation: The Inertial Reference System (IRS) receives data from three internal Ring Laser gyros (RLGs), and three internal accelerometers, measuring accelerations on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). Other data is also required, such as the: TAS - to calculate the wind speed/direction. Initial position – because actual aircraft position at any point during the flight, is calculated from the distance and direction flown from the initial reference position entered in the system. Barometric altitude – to stabilize the vertical navigation, thus stabilizing vertical velocity and inertial altitude information. The platform can output the inertial height by itself, but its accuracy is insufficient for precise height control, hence the barometric altitude input. The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground. A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform. Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary). Moreover, by detecting the drift due to the earth’s rotation, the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) will be able to internally calculate the True North. Latitude can also be internally calculated, but because this calculation is not sufficiently precise, a manual position input is required from the flight crew for this alignment sequence. Therefore, the system will compare the inserted latitude with the calculated one and compute precisely the aircraft’s position. On the other hand, the IRS cannot calculate/measure longitude, therefore the only reference is the one provided by the pilot during the alignment process.

options.B: indicated Airspeed (IAS) on the x, y and z axes.

key_points: Note: Obviously the wording is not very specific in this question, and we could use any further feedback for clarification on what EASA are asking
If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions
com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft
learning.explanation: Note: Obviously the wording is not very specific in this question, and we could use any further feedback for clarification on what EASA are asking. If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft. The basic principle is that, if an INS knows the initial location of the aircraft, and knows that it is completely still at that time (during initialisation), then it can precisely measure the aircraft's turns and accelerations to calculate its current position. It uses the mathematical process of integration to first work out the aircraft's velocity and direction, then integrates again to find the change in distance, which it then adds/removes from the original location. The oldest INSs use a "stable platform" design, which is a large platform that is kept pointing towards True North and perfectly upright, no matter the aircraft's heading or attitude. It manages this by using 3 rate-integrating gyros to measure the aircraft's turns around all three axes, and counter them by moving the platform the other way. It can then use 2 accelerometers to calculate the North-South acceleration, and the East-West accelerations, which are fed into a mechanical computer (a complex set of cogs and gears) that provide an output of speed and position, and other useful metrics. More modern aircraft use Inertial Reference Systems (IRSs), which are a form of INS, but are connected directly to the aircraft (no stable platform). These are much lighter, and less complex to have on board, as they use a set of 3 ring laser gyroscopes and 3 accelerometers to measure all the rotations and accelerations, and then calculates into their various components (North-South, East-West and Vertical) using modern computer methods. This is called a strapdown system, as it is fixed to the aircraft, and is much more usable with other systems, as it can feed info to the FMS, etc. This question is not very well worded, as the question is asking about inertial navigation systems, but the most correct answer (and the answer from feedback) is actually more related to IRSs. To clarify, we can go through each option: "true airspeed (TAS) on the x, y and z axes." This is quite blatantly wrong, airspeed is measured in one axis by the pitot tubes. "indicated Airspeed (IAS) on the x, y and z axes." Same as above, still wrong. "acceleration along the aircraft's pitch, roll and yaw axes." This one is nearly correct, as it does sense accelerations, but not necessarily along these axes (and these axes refer to rotations). INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions (and maybe vertically). "acceleration along the north-south, east-west and vertical axes." This is most correct, but only just. As mentioned above, INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions. They can sense vertical accelerations also, if they have a third accelerometer, but this is not so well documented in the learning objectives, and is more to do with IRSs, which all measure vertical acceleration as part of their normal process. This is why this question can garner some opposing views, depending on interpretation. So far, this is our best option.

content.question: What happens if one of the autopilots in a fail passive autoland system fails?

options.A: The airplane will continue flying normally, but the autoland could not be initiated.
options.B: Landing completed automatically.
options.C: The pilots should prepare for an out of trim condition.

key_points: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational

Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands
In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational. Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands. In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - The automatic landing system consists of three independent autopilot channels per controlled axis, it is capable of determining the failed component and excluding it from the computation. In the event of a failure, the approach, flare, and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system.
